title: Utrecht Housing
text:
The dataset contains the following columns








variable
description




id
Unique ID


zip_code4
Zip Code 4 digits


zip_code6
Zip Code 6 symbols


zip_code6_id
Zip Code 6 symbols ID


house_type
House Type: Apartment or House


lot_area
Lot Aream, sqm


house_area
House Area, sqm


garden_size
Garden Size, sqm


rooms
Number of Rooms


bathrooms
Number of Bathrooms


x_coor
X Coordinate


y_coor
Y Coordinate


build_year
Build Year


retail_value
Retail Value, kâ‚¬


asking_price
Asking Price, kâ‚¬


energy_label
Energy Label


energy_eff
Energy Efficiency


valuation_date
Valuation Date


street
Street Name


subdistrict
Subdistrict Name


district
District Name


city
City


dist_from_train
Distance from train, km

title: Practical 4: Data Wrangling + joins
text:
This is the tutorial for the first practical on Data Visualization with Plotnine

1 + 1

2




Code
import polars as pl
from plotnine import *
from gapminder import gapminder



#gapminder


(
ggplot(gapminder)+
geom_point(mapping=aes(x='gdpPercap', y='lifeExp', color='continent'))
)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
This is the tutorial for the first practical on Data Visualization with Plotnine
The objective of the tutorial is to give student a chance to practice the data visualization applying the skills learned through the video lessons on a new dataset.

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 1






Challenge



Reproduce this plot.

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 2






Challenge



Plot the (asked) price of the house against the number of rooms. Use color to indicate number of bathrooms in each house.

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 3






Challenge



How did the energy class of the houses change for the houses built during 20th and 21th century? How old is the newest house (woonhuis) in energy class B?
ðŸ’¡ You can limit the plot to the years between x1 and x2 using scale_x_continuous(limits=[x1, x2])

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 4






Challenge



Reproduce this plot.
ðŸ’¡ If you want to match the color palette as well, itâ€™s qualitative brewer scale number 2
ðŸ’¡ You can add multi-line strings in Python using triple quotes like this """long string which may span multiple lines"""

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 5






Challenge



Plot retail prices by district. Which district has highest median prices and which has the lowest? Flip the coordinates using coord_flip() to see the district names more clearly.

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 6






Challenge



Plot the distribution of retail values for the two types of houses. Which of these distributions look more symmetrical?

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 7






Challenge



Plot property prices vs the house size for each district using small multiples. Add a blue linear regression to each subplot. Which district shows the steepest slope of the regression line? Which one shows the shallowest slope?

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 8






Challenge



What do you think are the approximate coordinates of the train station? In which district do you think it might be located? What do you think is the zip code of the train station? (Google to check your answer)

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 9






Challenge



Plot the house prices vs living area coloring point by the property grade.

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 10






Challenge



Do newer houses cost more? Do higher grade houses cost more? Are newer houses higher grade?
ðŸ’¡ Put the house price on log scale to avoid overplotting

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 11






Challenge



Visualize distribution of price per square foot of living area for properties in each of the housing conditions. Would you say that newer houses tend to be in better condition?

title: Practical 1: Data Visualization
text:
Challenge 12






Challenge



Visualize distribution of price per square foot of living area for water-facing properties and the non-water facing properties. Which of the distributions look more symmetrical?

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text: The objective of the tutorial is to give student a chance to practice the data visualization and data wrangling applying the skills learned through the video lessons on a new dataset.

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Preparation






Note



Before you begin your peer-programming session, please, start the new Jupyter notebook environment in your terminal using the command you learned in Module 1 of the course.
uv run jupyter lab
Create a new notebook and add a text cell atop your document for this practical session. Add a header # Data Visualization and wrangling. Then add a code cell and place the following code there.

import polars as pl
import polars.selectors as cs
from plotnine import *

Then import the datasets for this practical. Add another code cell below (using the key â€˜Bâ€™) and paste the following code. This will import two datasets we will be using in the session: Utrecht and Kingâ€™s County.

ut = pl.read_csv("https://rrr.is/data24utrecht", try_parse_dates=True)
kc = pl.read_csv('https://rrr.is/data24kingscounty', try_parse_dates=True)

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 1






Challenge



What is the average garden size for the houses in Utrecht dataset? What is the median distance from train?

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 2






Challenge



Create a plot of house area vs lot area for the â€˜woonhuisâ€™ properties. Add a linear trend line. Can you identify at least a couple outliers from the general trend? What is an approximate lot area that you would predict using this model for a house of 200 sqm?
ðŸ’¡ Remember, that you can pass the data to plotnine using .pipe() method.

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 3






Challenge



Are the outliers you identified in the previous plot also outliers with regards to the relationship between the house area and the asking price? Are these outliers correspond to the newer or older houses? Are they located close by to each other? Whatâ€™s their 4 digit zip-code?

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 4






Challenge



Create a small dataset which includes only houses from the zipcode(s) identified in the previous challenge. Show the street name, house size, lot area, build year, energy class and the asking price. How many houses are in your dataset? Arrange the observations by the year these houses were built. What is the street name in which the oldest of these houses is located?

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 5






Challenge



Plot the line showing the average house size per decade in the 20th century. How many peaks in the house sizes can you identify?
ðŸ’¡ The whole number division in Python is denoted with //

title: Practical 2: Data Visualization + Wrangling
text:
Challenge 6






Challenge



Calculate the averate square meter price per valuation week using retail value and plot it. Do you see any trend in the development of real estate prices?
ðŸ’¡ Measure per square meter price as retail value divided by house area
ðŸ’¡ You can convert the date into the ISO week number using .dt.week() method

title: Kings County Housing
text:
The dataset contains the following columns








variable
description




id
Unique ID for each home sold


date
Date of the home sale


price
Price of each home sold


bedrooms
Number of bedrooms


bathrooms
Number of bathrooms


sqft_living
Square footage of the apartments interior living space


sqft_lot
Square footage of the land space


floors
Number of floors


waterfront
A dummy variable for whether the apartment was overlooking the waterfront or not


view
An index from 0 to 4 of how good the view of the property was


condition
An index from 1 to 5 on the condition of the apartment


grade
An index from 1 to 13 where 1-3 falls short of building construction and design, 7 has an average level of construction and design and 11-13 have a high quality level of construction and design


sqft_above
Square footage of the interior housing space above ground level


sqft_basement
Square footage of the interior housing space below ground level


yr_built
Year the house was initially built


yr_renovated
Year of the houseâ€™s last renovation and, if not renovated, the year built


zipcode
Zipcode the house belongs to


lat
Latitude


long
Longitude


sqft_living15
Average square footage of the apartments interior living space for the nearest 15 neighbors


sqft_lot15
Average square footage of the land space for the nearest 15 neighbors
